items.title: Projected impact of combined high-end atmospheric carbon dioxide levels and tree restoration on albedo, forest emissions and carbon uptake
items.body:
Download PDF

Article
    
        
            Open access

Published: 14 January 2026

Projected impact of combined high-end atmospheric carbon dioxide levels and tree restoration on albedo, forest emissions and carbon uptake
                    Robert J. Allen 
            ORCID: orcid.org/0000-0003-1616-97191, Taylor Adkins 
            ORCID: orcid.org/0009-0001-0914-43131 & Olivia E. Clifton2

Communications Sustainability

volume 1, Article number: 11 (2026)
            Cite this article

Subjects
        
            Climate and Earth system modellingClimate-change mitigation

AbstractTree restoration is seen as a nature-based solution to climate change, because trees remove carbon from the atmosphere. However, tree cover can influence surface temperatures in other ways, for example by changing albedo and enhancing evapotranspiration. These impacts may, in turn, be affected by increasing atmospheric carbon dioxide concentrations. Here, we present simulations with a coupled atmosphere-land-slab-ocean model to investigate how doubled atmospheric carbon dioxide levels affect warming in a high-end scenario where afforestation covers a land area 35% larger than the USA. Changes in albedo, changes in evapotranspiration, and forest biogenic volatile organic compound emissions combined result in reduced warming by 0.06+/-0.04 K in the afforestation scenario with doubled carbon dioxide scenario, compared with afforestation in a baseline scenario with present-day carbon dioxide levels. This reduced warming is largely due to less snow in the Northern Hemisphere and thus less surface darkening.  Similarly, tree carbon sequestration enhances cooling by 0.20 K in the afforestation/doubled carbon dioxide scenario, compared to an afforestation/present-day carbon dioxide scenario. We conclude that in a world with doubled atmospheric carbon dioxide concentrations, the climate mitigation potential of tree restoration is only minimally affected.

IntroductionNatural climate solutions are activities that store carbon and reduce greenhouse gas emissions by protecting, restoring and better managing nature1,2,3. For example, large-scale tree restoration (including reforestation and afforestation) can play a role in global climate change mitigation4,5,6,7. The number of trees has decreased by nearly 50% since the onset of human civilization (from about 6 to 3 trillion trees), highlighting the potential for significant restoration8.Quantifying the impacts associated with tree restoration requires addressing both biogeochemical and biogeophysical processes. Trees sequester atmospheric carbon dioxide (CO2), resulting in biogeochemical cooling. However, trees also drive regionally dependent biogeophysical effects, such as reduced surface albedo which promotes warming and increased evapotranspiration (ET) which contributes to cooling9,10,11,12,13,14,15,16,17. Surface roughness is another biogeophysical factor affecting surface temperature responses to (de)forestation18. Prior studies13,19 show that tropical trees lead to a cooling effect (largely due to enhanced ET), but extratropical trees, especially in the boreal region where significant snow cover exists, have a warming effect (largely due to surface darkening).In addition, the atmospheric chemistry implications of tree restoration are likely important20,21,22,23,24, but seldom considered. Trees emit biogenic volatile organic compounds (BVOCs), which can reduce the oxidative capacity of the atmosphere and thus increase methane (CH4), which promotes warming. Although more complicated due to dependence on the local chemical environment, most of the above studies also show that tree restoration increases tropospheric ozone (O3), which is also a greenhouse gas. Simultaneously, BVOCs can promote the formation of secondary organic aerosol (SOA), which leads to a cooling effect. A recent study found that the chemistry effects of a high-end tree restoration perturbation led to net cooling, largely due to aerosol and cloud effects (with the cooling dampened by enhanced warming from methane)24. Furthermore, as tree restoration is a multi-decadal to century-long process, the impact of continued atmospheric CO2 increases on the efficacy of tree restoration remains underexplored. Climate-related tree restoration concerns include increased risk of drought and wild fire activity, shifts in regional water availability, changes in wind break, as well as biotic factors25,26,27,28.Here, we examine the chemistry-climate response (which includes biogeophysical effects, including atmospheric chemistry) to a high-end tree restoration scenario under present-day (year 2000) atmospheric CO2 concentrations (~370 ppm) and double present-day atmospheric CO2 concentrations (~740 ppm). We note that 740 ppm is a relatively large amount of atmospheric CO2, but it lies in between the “middle-of-the-road”, intermediate greenhouse gas (GHG) emissions scenario SSP2-4.5 (~567 ppm in 2100) and the “regional rivalry”, high GHG emissions scenario SSP3-7.0 (~834 ppm by 2100). Two sets of Community Atmosphere Model versions 6 (CAM6)29 present-day time-slice simulations with interactive atmospheric chemistry30 coupled to the Community Land Model version 5 (CLM5)31 and a slab ocean model (SOM) are performed (Methods), including a tree restoration experiment and a baseline control (for both CO2 values). Subtracting the control experiment from the tree restoration experiment yields the chemistry-climate response to the high-end tree restoration scenario, which is abbreviated as \({{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{2{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}}\) (under double present-day CO2 concentrations; Supplementary Table 1) and \({{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{1{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}}\) (under present-day CO2 concentrations). The corresponding impact of the higher CO2 on the chemistry–climate effects of tree restoration is calculated as \({{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{2x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}_2}-{{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{1{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}}\). Our experimental design, therefore, allows quantification of the impact of atmospheric CO2 on the efficacy of tree restoration. All simulations use prescribed atmospheric CO2 concentrations and therefore do not explicitly include the biogeochemical effects of tree restoration on climate (e.g., temperature). However, biogeochemical effects can be approximated offline using the transient climate response to cumulative CO2 emissions (TCRE)32,33,34,35. Furthermore, all simulations use prescribed near-surface methane concentrations and thus do not explicitly include changes in methane via the main atmospheric oxidant (the hydroxyl radical or OH) and thus changes in methane’s radiative effects; however, OH is dynamically simulated, and the temperature response to changes in methane lifetime due to OH is calculated offline. We emphasize that such offline calculations exclude important feedback. Finally, we note that our study directly aligns with Sustainable Development Goal 13 of the United Nations, which involves taking urgent action to combat climate change and its impacts36.ResultsTree restoration scenarioOur tree perturbation, along with changes in crop, grass and shrub, is shown in Supplementary Fig. 1. As this perturbation is identical to that in ref. 24 (details on the procedure are discussed in Supplementary Note 1), we summarize the key statistics here. Global tree area increases by 12.31 Mkm2 (~135% of the area of the United States) with temperate trees increasing by 5.98 Mkm2, followed by tropical trees at 5.57 Mkm2 and boreal trees at 0.77 Mkm2. Grass decreases by −8.16 Mkm2, crop decreases by −4.17 Mkm2 and barren land decreases by −0.15 Mkm2, with small increases in shrub at 0.16 Mkm2. Northern Hemisphere (NH) tree restoration accounts for 66% (8.10 Mkm2) of the global increase and consists largely of temperate trees at 5.04 Mkm2. Southern Hemisphere (SH) tree restoration accounts for 34% (4.21 Mkm2) of the global increase, which is dominated by tropical trees at 3.26 Mkm2.As we conduct time-slice simulations, the tree restoration perturbation is instantaneously imposed. Although this is less realistic than a transient simulation (i.e., trees are added incrementally through time19,37), a time-slice simulation (particularly one with a relatively large tree restoration signal) allows us to maximize the signal-to-noise ratio, to identify robust responses and to understand the dominant mechanisms. Thus, we focus on a biophysical upper limit of tree restoration with the goal of understanding robust responses and the dominant driving mechanisms.Near-surface air temperature responseFigure 1 shows the near-surface air temperature (Tas) response to tree restoration. Under \({{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{1{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}}\) (Fig. 2b), significant global mean warming of 0.07 ± 0.03 K (Table 1) occurs, but with a hemispheric contrast. Nearly all of the warming occurs in the NH at 0.19 ± 0.03 K, with much larger warming (e.g., central US; central Russia) over regions with large increases in tree fraction. In contrast, much of the SH cools at −0.04 ± 0.03 K, again with larger cooling (e.g., southeast Brazil) over regions with large increases in tree fraction (Supplementary Fig. 1d). Under \({{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{2{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}}\) (Fig. 2a), the global mean Tas response is reduced to nonsignificant warming of \(0.02\pm 0.03\) K (Table 1). Again, however, a hemispheric contrast exists (but muted) as the NH exhibits significant warming of 0.07 ± 0.04 K, whereas the SH exhibits significant cooling of −0.04 ± 0.03 K. Thus, the impact of the higher CO2 i.e., (\({{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{2{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}}-{{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{1{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}}\)) yields global mean cooling of −0.06 ± 0.04 K, which is due to cooling of the NH at −0.12 ± 0.05 K (Table 1). This latter result is a bit unexpected, since ref. 24 showed SH cooling under \({{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{1{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}}\) was largely associated with enhanced SOA and cloud effects. As \({{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{2{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}}\) yields larger increases in SOA as compared to \({{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{1{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}}\), we would have expected a stronger cooling associated with aerosol direct and indirect effects. We explain the minimal impact on SH Tas below.Fig. 1: Near-surface air temperature response to global tree restoration.Results are based on a \({{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{2{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}}\), b \({{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{1{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}}\) and c \({{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{2{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}}-{{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{1{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}}\). Responses are estimated from CAM6 simulations with interactive atmospheric chemistry coupled to a slab ocean model over the last 150 years of the simulation (years 50–199). Black dots show changes significant at the 90% confidence level based on a standard t-test. Units are K.Full size imageFig. 2: Surface energy balance (SEB) decomposition of the surface temperature response.Annual mean SEB responses for the a Northern Hemisphere and b Southern Hemisphere. SEB terms include surface albedo (purple); downwelling surface shortwave radiation (SW; cyan) and its clear-sky (SWclear; yellow) and cloudy-sky (SWcloud; green) contributions; downwelling surface longwave radiation (LW; red) and its clear-sky (LWclear; blue) and cloudy-sky (LWcloud; navy) contributions; surface latent heat flux (LHF; orange); surface sensible heat flux (SHF; gray); and near-surface air temperature (Tas; black). To isolate the contribution from the tree restoration perturbation, the SEB decomposition is performed over land areas where the change in tree fraction is at least 0.1. Results are based on simulations with interactive atmospheric chemistry under \({{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{2{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}}\) (1st bar in each like colored set of 3 bars) and \({{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{1{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}}\) (2nd bar in each like colored set of 3 bars). \({{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{2{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}}-{{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{1{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}}\) is shown as the 3rd bar in each like colored set of 3 bars. Error bars show the 90% confidence interval. Units are K.Full size imageTable 1 Near-surface air temperature responses under tree restoration in simulations with interactive atmospheric chemistry.Full size tableCAM6 constrains CH4 to specified surface concentrations, which inhibits changes in its atmospheric concentration. Several modeling studies show that the oxidative capacity of the atmosphere under tree restoration decreases through enhanced BVOC emissions and subsequent decrease in OH concentrations23,24,38. However, uncertainties exist with respect to our understanding of how much OH is consumed by isoprene oxidation and how to represent radical recycling in global models39,40,41,42,43,44. This would increase the CH4 lifetime and its concentration, as well as tropospheric O3 and stratospheric water vapor. Thus, the change in CH4 concentration that would be expected is estimated from the change in its lifetime due to reaction with OH45,46 (see the “Methods” section).The direct and indirect effect of increased CH4 leads to an estimated global mean warming of 0.13 K (0.08–0.17 K) under \({{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{2{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}}\) and 0.04 K (0.03–0.06 K) under \({{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{1{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}}\) (see the “Methods” section; Table 1). This methane effect, therefore, shifts the aforementioned biogeophysical cooling under \({{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{2{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}}-{{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{1{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}}\) to a net warming. For example, the global mean near-surface air temperature response increases from 0.02 to 0.15 K under \({{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{2{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}}\) and from 0.07 to 0.11 K under \({{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{1x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}}\) when methane effects are accounted for, i.e., \({{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{2{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}}-{{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{1{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}}\) increases from \(-0.06\) to 0.04 K.Surface energy balance decompositionWe use the surface energy balance (SEB; see the “Methods” section) decomposition35,47,48 to help understand the drivers of the temperature responses discussed above. Our SEB analysis is performed over land areas that feature an increase in tree fraction of at least 0.1, which therefore provides a regional evaluation of the drivers of the temperature response to tree restoration. By restricting the SEB analysis to regions of relatively large tree fraction increases, we are isolating the local impacts of tree restoration on surface temperature, and radiative and turbulent heat fluxes. Nonetheless, we find similar (but weaker) results when the SEB analysis is applied to all land areas (e.g., Supplementary Fig. 2). We first highlight that the SEB estimate of the change in surface temperature (Ts) is similar to that simulated. For example, the SEB estimate of the global mean Ts response is \(-0.14\pm 0.04\) K under \({{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{2{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}}\) and \(0.12\pm 0.04\) K under \({{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{1{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}}\) (Supplementary Table 2). The corresponding simulated Ts responses are \(-0.16\pm 0.04\) and \(0.08\pm 0.04\) K, respectively.Figure 2 shows a bar chart of each of the SEB terms for the NH and SH under \({{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{2{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}}\) (1st bar in each like colored set of 3 bars), \({{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{2{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}}\) (2nd bar in each like colored set of 3 bars) and \({{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{2{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}}-{{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{1{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}}\) (3rd bar in each like colored set of 3 bars). In the NH (Fig. 2a), the albedo term is an important driver of the muted surface warming under \({{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{2{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}}\), as it decreases from \(0.56\pm 0.02\) K under \({{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{1{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}}\) to \(0.41\pm 0.01\) K under \({{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{2{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}}\) (Supplementary Table 2). In other words, less surface darkening occurs in response to the same tree restoration under \({{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{1{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}}\).The warming associated with the albedo term under both \({{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{2{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}}\) and \({{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{1{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}}\) is consistent with the relatively low albedo of trees, i.e., tree restoration typically increases surface darkening (decreases albedo) compared to other surfaces such as bare ground or snow. In addition to the underlying surface, the amount of tree restoration (e.g., as quantified through leaf area index, LAI) is also important, i.e., a larger increase in LAI would be expected to lead to more surface darkening and hence, warming. Although the tree restoration perturbation is identical (in terms of tree area) between \({{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{2{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}}\) and \({{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{1{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}}\), LAI (and other vegetation indices) increases more under \({{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{2{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}}\), which is consistent with the CO2 fertilization effect. For example, \({{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{2{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}}-{{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{1{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}}\) yields net LAI increases (similarly subsampled as the SEB analysis) of \(0.19\pm 0.01\) m2 m−2 in the NH (\(0.39\pm 0.02\) m2 m−2 in the SH). This larger LAI increase under \({{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{2{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}}\), however, is inconsistent with the weaker surface darkening under \({{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{2{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}}\), implying the importance of the underlying surface. Specifically, there is less snow in \({{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{2{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}}\) due to the warmer background climate. Snow depth over land decreases by \(-61\)% in the NH under the 2 × CO2 base climate relative to the 1 × CO2 base climate. In other words, putting the same tree perturbation over areas with minimal snow versus areas with extensive snow yields less surface darkening.This is further supported by additional analyses. Examining the albedo effect by season shows the dominant seasonal warming effect in the NH occurs during March, April, May (MAM) at \(0.48\pm 0.01\) K under \({{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{2{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}}\) and \(0.85\pm 0.04\) K under \({{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{1{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}}\). The larger snow cover in the \({{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{1{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}}\) baseline climate yields a larger warming (surface darkening) effect. Consistently, \({{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{2{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}}-{{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{1{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}}\) yields the strongest NH seasonal cooling associated with the albedo term in MAM at \(-0.37\pm 0.04\) K. This is followed by December, January, February (DJF) at \(-0.24\pm 0.03\) K. Both of these responses are consistent with co-occurrence of snow and vegetation. The larger response in MAM is consistent with more sunlight. In contrast, June, July, August (JJA) yields net NH warming of the albedo term under \({{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{2{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}}-{{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{1{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}}\) at \(0.06\pm 0.01\) K. This NH JJA warming is consistent with the importance of the enhanced LAI under \({{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{2{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}}-{{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{1{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}}\), suggesting that leaves are darker than soil generally in the NH and this enhanced LAI further darkens the surface. Consistently, LAI also has an NH maximum seasonal increase under \({{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{2{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}}-{{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{1{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}}\) during JJA. Thus, the overall impact (annual mean) of the albedo term is to drive net cooling under \({{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{2{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}}-{{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{1{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}}\), largely during MAM and DJF, due to less snow in the warmer background climate of \({{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{2{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}}\).”The muted NH surface warming under \({{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{2{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}}\) is also associated with the downwelling surface shortwave radiation (SW) term, which becomes more negative under \({{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{2{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}}\) at \(-0.21\pm 0.03\) K as compared to \({{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{1{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}}\) at \(-0.11\pm 0.03\) K. Nearly all of this is associated with the clear-sky SW (SWclear) term, as opposed to the cloudy-sky SW (SWcloud) term. The larger decrease in SWclear under \({{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{2{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}}\) is consistent with larger increases in BVOCs and SOA under \({{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{2{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}}\), leading to enhanced scattering of solar radiation (discussed below). As BVOC emissions are strongly a function of temperature in the MEGAN model49, the same tree restoration under the warmer \({{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{2{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}}\) climate yields a larger BVOC increase, and in turn, more SOA. We note that a decrease in NH dust burden acts to weaken the SOA-driven enhanced scattering of solar radiation under both \({{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{2{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}}\) and \({{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{1{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}}\) (Supplementary Table 3), but non-significant NH dust decreases occur under \({{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{2{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}}-{{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{1{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}}\) at \(-0.36\pm 1.4\) Tg.\({{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{2{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}}-{{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{1{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}}\) in the NH also yields cooling (i.e., less warming under \({{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{2{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}}\) as compared to \({{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{1{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}}\)) for the downwelling surface longwave radiation (LW) term, which is largely associated with the clear-sky LW (LWclear) term. We suggest that this is largely a temperature-induced feedback as opposed to a driver of the surface temperature response50. Less surface warming under \({{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{2{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}}\) yields less upwards surface LW radiation (consistent with the Stefan–Boltzmann law whereby a blackbody radiates energy proportional to Ts4) and, via the atmospheric greenhouse effect, less downwelling LW radiation.The sensible heat flux (SHF) term shows relatively strong cooling in the NH under both \({{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{2{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}}\) and \({{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{1{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}}\). Although this is qualitatively consistent with increased surface roughness due to tree restoration (i.e., increased surface roughness should promote an increase in sensible heat flux and, in turn, surface cooling), we note opposite changes occur in the SH (i.e., the SHF term shows warming; discussed below). As suggested by ref. 24, changes in the SHF term under tree restoration appear to be a consequence of the surface temperature response. As the NH surface warms (here, largely due to surface darkening), surface sensible heat flux increases and acts to offset this warming (i.e., the SHF term yields cooling). Similarly, from a surface energy balance standpoint, an increase in surface solar radiation (again, largely due to surface darkening here) implies a decrease in other terms of the surface energy balance, such as sensible heat flux. Unlike some studies18, we therefore do not find strong support for the importance of increased surface roughness on the surface energy balance and corresponding surface temperature response.The above argument also helps to explain the NH SHF term warming under \({{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{2{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}}-{{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{1{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}}\) (i.e., the SHF term shows stronger cooling under \({{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{1{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}}\) as compared to \({{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{2{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}}\)). As the NH surface warms more under \({{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{1{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}}\), surface sensible heat flux increases more and acts to cool the surface more. As \({{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{2{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}}-{{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{1{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}}\) yields surface cooling, this implies less sensible heat flux and a net warming effect, i.e., the correlation between the NH SHF term and the NH near-surface air temperature response across \({{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{1{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}}\), \({{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{2{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}}\) and \({{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{2{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}}-{{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{1{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}}\) is \(-0.98\). Similarly, the change in total surface shortwave radiation (albedo and SW terms) contributes, as more (less) total solar radiation promotes an increase (decrease) in turbulent heat fluxes and their associated cooling (warming) effects. For example, the total surface shortwave radiation term increases by \(0.45\pm 0.04\) K under \({{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{1{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}}\) versus \(0.20\pm 0.03\) K under \({{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{2{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}}\). Consistently, \({{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{1{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}}\) yields larger SHF term cooling at \(-0.34\pm 0.02\) K (and larger surface warming) as compared to that under \({{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{2{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}}\) \(-0.20\pm 0.02\) K. The corresponding total surface shortwave radiation term under \({{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{2{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}}-{{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{1{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}}\) is cooling at \(-0.25\pm 0.04\) K, consistent with SHF term warming (\(0.14\pm 0.03\) K) and surface cooling. The correlation between the NH SHF term and the NH total surface shortwave radiation term across \({{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{1{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}}\), \({{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{2{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}}\) and \({{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{2{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}}-{{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{1{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}}\) is \(-0.99\). This, however, supports our overall argument in that the temperature change in the NH under \({{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{2{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}}-{{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{1{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}}\) is driven by albedo and SW terms, with amplifying feedbacks via the LW term and dampening feedbacks via the SHF term. We note that changes in the LHF term are all relatively small but negative (i.e., tree restoration yields enhanced ET, but not that much cooling in the NH).Thus, in the NH, most of the muted warming under \({{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{2{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}}\) is driven by the less surface darkening (smaller warming from the albedo term) due to less snow and by a larger decrease in surface clear-sky downwelling shortwave radiation (larger cooling from the SWclear term) due to more biogenic aerosols. We note that the relatively weak NH SWcloud cooling found here (over land areas with >0.1 tree fraction increase) is more substantial in our subsequent analyses below. We also note that performing the SEB analysis over all land regions yields similar conclusions (Supplementary Fig. 2a).In the SH (Fig. 2b), enhanced surface temperature cooling under \({{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{2{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}}-{{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{1{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}}\) is relatively small and not significant. The albedo term contributes only a small amount of cooling at \(-0.02\pm 0.01\) K. This is related to differences in the location of tree restoration between hemispheres, as SH tree restoration primarily occurs in the lower latitudes (e.g., Supplementary Fig. 1d). Here, less snow exists (as compared to higher latitudes), such that tree restoration in a warmer world has less of a surface darkening muting effect. Furthermore, snow depth over land decreases by only \(-15\)% in the SH (versus \(-61\)% in the NH) under the \({{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{2{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}}\) base climate relative to the \({{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{1{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}}\) base climate.Enhanced SH cooling under \({{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{2{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}}-{{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{1{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}}\) is largely associated with the SW term (\(-0.10\pm 0.07\) K), due to a relatively large contribution from the SWclear term at \(-0.26\pm 0.02\) K. This is again consistent with an increase in BVOCs and SOA under \({{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{2{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}}\) (both of which increase more in the SH as opposed to the NH), leading to enhanced scattering of solar radiation (discussed below). As in the NH, a decrease in SH dust burden acts to weaken the SOA-driven enhanced scattering of solar radiation under both \({{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{2{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}}\) and \({{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{1{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}}\) (Supplementary Table 3).In contrast to SWclear, the SWcloud term becomes less negative under \({{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{2{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}}\), resulting in a net warming of \(0.16\pm 0.07\) K under \({{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{2{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}}-{{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{1{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}}\) that offsets some of the net cooling from the SWclear term. Clouds are discussed below, but we note the larger SWcloud cooling under \({{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{1{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}}\) as compared to \({{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{2{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}}\) is consistent with a larger increase in low cloud cover (similarly subsampled as the SEB analysis) at \(0.93\pm 0.05\)% under \({{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{1{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}}\) versus \(0.68\pm 0.13\)% under \({{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{2{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}}\). The ability of forests to increase low cloud cover is consistent with recent observational studies51,52.As in the NH, the SH LW term also promotes cooling under \({{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{2{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}}-{{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{1{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}}\), but we again suggest this is a temperature-induced feedback. The LHF and SHF terms individually promote net (nonsignificant) warming under \({{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{2{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}}-{{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{1{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}}\) at 0.05 ± 0.06 K for both. The SHF term warming response is consistent with the above suggestion that it is largely a consequence of the surface cooling. For example, \({{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{2{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}}\) features both larger surface cooling and larger SHF term warming as compared to \({{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{1{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}}\). The corresponding \({{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{2{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}}-{{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{1{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}}\) yields the weakest surface cooling as well as the weakest SHF warming, i.e., the correlation between the SH SHF term and the SH near-surface air temperature response across \({{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{1{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}}\), \({{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{2{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}}\) and \({{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{2{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}}-{{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{1{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}}\) is \(-0.93\).Under both \({{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{2{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}}\) and \({{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{1{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}}\), relatively large surface cooling in the SH is associated with the LHF term, implying strong ET cooling effects from SH trees. There is a weaker cooling from LHF under \({{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{2{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}}\) than \({{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{1{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}}\). This is related to larger increases in canopy transpiration yet larger decreases in evaporation under \({{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{2{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}}\). Canopy transpiration (similarly subsampled as the SEB analysis) under \({{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{2{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}}-{{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{1{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}}\) yields an increase of \(0.65\pm 0.17\) W m−2 in the SH. This increase in canopy transpiration under \({{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{2{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}}-{{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{1{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}}\) is consistent with the larger increases in vegetation indices (due to CO2 fertilization) under \({{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{2{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}}\) as compared to \({{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{1{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}}\). As noted above, LAI increases more (similarly subsampled as the SEB analysis) under \({{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{2{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}}\) as compared to \({{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{1{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}}\). Stomatal closure under high CO2 may limit canopy transpiration increases, but this effect appears to be weaker than the more leafy biomass under high CO2.The net warming of the SH LHF term under \({{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{2{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}}-{{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{1{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}}\) is consistent with the net decrease in the SW term (here, the albedo term is small). That is, less downwelling surface solar radiation implies less energy for evaporation. Evaporation (similarly subsampled as the SEB analysis) decreases by \(-0.82\pm 0.12\) W m−2 under \({{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{1{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}}\) and \(-1.50\pm 0.19\) W m−2 under \({{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{2{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}}\) and thus decreases by \(-0.68\pm 0.22\) W m−2 under \({{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{2{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}}-{{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{1{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}}\). As the decrease in the SW term is largely due to SWclear (which is related to the increase in SOA), this implies that any enhanced cooling from an increase in SOA under \({{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{2{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}}-{{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{1{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}}\) is in part offset by reductions in latent cooling. A somewhat similar effect has been noted in response to anthropogenic aerosols, where tree restoration leads to enhanced cooling under reduced air pollution due to increased turbulent heat flux cooling associated with the enhanced surface SW radiation53.Thus, \({{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{2{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}}-{{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{1{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}}\) yields relatively small impacts on surface temperature in the SH because the albedo effect is weak and the enhanced SWclear cooling is muted by net warming from the SWcloud and turbulent heat flux terms. In general, similar but weaker results occur for the SEB analysis over all land (Supplementary Fig. 2b). Additional details on the LHF term are discussed below and in Supplementary Note 2, where the LHF term is decomposed into canopy transpiration, canopy evaporation and ground evaporation SEB terms.Aerosols, cloud and ozone-related responsesFigure 3 shows zonal mean changes in aerosol and ozone-related variables (see also Supplementary Table 3). As mentioned above, tree restoration is associated with an increase in the emissions of BVOCs, including isoprene (Fig. 3a) and monoterpene (Fig. 3b), with larger increases under \({{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{2{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}}\), particularly in the SH. For example, SH isoprene emissions (land-only) increase by \(173.5\pm 5.2\) Tg year−1 under \({{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{2{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}}\) versus \(80.2\pm 2.1\) Tg year−1 under \({{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{1{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}}\). The larger BVOC increase under \({{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{2{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}}\) is consistent with the aforementioned temperature dependence of BVOC emissions49; the larger BVOC increase in the SH is consistent with the dominance of tropical trees in our SH tree restoration (as opposed to temperate or boreal trees), which are stronger emitters of most isoprene46. Consistent with these BVOC changes, \({{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{2{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}}\) yields a larger increase in SOA burden (Fig. 3c) as compared to \({{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{1{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}}\), particularly in the SH (\(0.37\pm 0.01\,\)Tg under \({{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{2{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}}\) versus \(0.11\pm 0.01\) Tg under \({{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{1{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}}\)). Such changes in BVOCs and SOA are qualitatively consistent with prior tree restoration/land use change analyses23,24,54.Fig. 3: Aerosol, cloud and ozone-related responses.Zonal annual mean responses (over all land and ocean) for a isoprene emissions [μg m−2 s−1]; b monoterpene emissions [μg m−2 s−1]; c secondary organic aerosol (SOA) burden [mg m−2]; d aerosol optical depth (AOD; unitless); e aerosol direct radiative effect (ADRE) at the TOA [W m−2]; f cloud radiative effect at the TOA [W m−2]; g tropospheric ozone (TO3) burden [DU]; h hydroxyl radical (OH) burden [ng m−2]; and nitrogen oxide (NOx) burden [mg m−2]. Again, this is more pronounced in the SH, where ADRE decreases by \(-0.15\pm 0.02\) W m−2 under \({{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{2{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}}\) versus \(-0.04\pm 0.01\) W m−2 under \({{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{1{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}}\). In contrast, the TOA cloud radiative effect (CRE; Fig. 3f) is less negative under \({{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{2{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}}\). In the SH, the CRE is \(-0.13\pm 0.07\) W m−2 versus \(-0.22\pm 0.11\) W m−2 under \({{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{2{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}}\) and \({{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{1{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}}\), respectively (Supplementary Table 4). The corresponding \({{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{2{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}}-{{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{1{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}}\) is positive but not significant in both hemispheres at \(0.09\pm 0.13\) W m−2 in the SH and \(0.08\pm 0.11\) W m-2 in the NH. The strengthening (more negative) of the ADRE but weakening (less negative) of the CRE under \({{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{2{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}}\) as compared to \({{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{1{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}}\) is emphasized in Supplementary Fig. 3. We note that this weakening of the CRE (albeit non-significant) applies to both hemispheres. These zonal mean results are in general consistent with the SEB decomposition (which only includes land areas with >0.1 tree fraction change), where the influence of SWclear (which is impacted by aerosol direct effect) is more negative (i.e., stronger) under \({{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{2{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}}\) than \({{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{1{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}}\), yet the influence of SWcloud (in the SH) is less negative (i.e., weaker). On the other hand, these zonal mean results suggest that the reduced cooling from clouds under \({{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{2{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}}\) is also important in the higher-latitude NH (where it was weak based on the SEB analysis; Fig. 2a).We also note larger tropospheric ozone (TO3) burden decreases in the SH under \({{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{2{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}}\) (Fig. 3g), larger decreases in OH burden at all latitudes (Fig. 3h) under \({{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{2{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}}\) and similar decreases in nitrogen oxide (NOx) burden across most latitudes for both \({{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{2{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}}\) and \({{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{1{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}}\). The larger SH TO3 decrease under \({{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{2{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}}\) (\(-0.59\pm 0.04\) DU versus \(-0.19\pm 0.04\) DU under \({{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{1{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}}\)) is consistent with the larger increase in BVOCs (e.g., isoprene; Fig. 3a), which are oxidized by TO3 and OH. The NH TO3 increase (largely in the NH mid-latitudes) is consistent with the increase in BVOCs (especially isoprene) under higher climatological NOx concentrations (Fig. 3i), which drives TO3 production. Here, the NH TO3 increase is weaker under \({{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{2{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}}\) (\(0.03\pm 0.05\) DU versus \(0.12\pm 0.04\) DU under \({{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{1{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}}\)), which is largely related to stronger TO3 decreases in the NH tropics (where NOx is relatively low). The larger decrease in SH TO3 (a greenhouse gas) under \({{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{2{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}}\) is inconsistent with the similar SH near-surface air temperature response under \({{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{2{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}}\) and \({{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{1{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}}\), suggesting the change in TO3 is not a dominant contributor to the surface temperature response. This is consistent with ref. 24, where the global annual mean ozone instantaneous radiative effect associated with our tree restoration perturbation under \({{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{1{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}}\) is very small at \(0.001\pm 0.00023\) W m−2 (\(-0.005\pm 0.00025\) W m−2 in the SH and \(0.006\pm 0.00045\) W m−2 in the NH).Air quality responsesFigure 4 shows changes in near-surface fine particulate matter (PM2.5), a commonly used quantity to diagnose air quality. In the NH, PM2.5 over land increases under \({{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{2{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}}\) (\(0.39\pm 0.12\) μg m−3) with weak decreases under \({{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{1{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}}\) (\(-0.07\pm 0.12\) μg m−3; although some regions like North America yield increases). The weak decrease under \({{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{1{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}}\) is related to compensating increases in SOA but decreases in dust (Supplementary Table 3). The net PM2.5 increase under \({{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{2{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}}-{{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{1{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}}\) (\(0.46\pm 0.17\) μg m−3) is due to the larger increase in SOA dominating over weaker decreases in dust. In the SH, both \({{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{2{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}}\) and \({{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{1{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}}\) yield increases in PM2.5 over land at \(1.10\pm 0.07\) and \(0.31\pm 0.07\) μg m−3, respectively, with net increases under \({{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{2{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}}-{{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{1{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}}\) (\(0.79\pm 0.10\) μg m−3). Increases are particularly prominent over Brazil, where PM2.5 increases exceed 10 μg m−3 under \({{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{2{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}}\).Fig. 4: Near-surface fine particulate matter responses to global tree restoration.Near-surface fine particulate matter (PM2.5; μg m−3) a–c spatial maps and d, e zonal mean land-only responses. Spatial maps are based on simulations under a \({{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{2{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}}\), b \({{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{1{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}}\), and c \({{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{2{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}}-{{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{1{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}}\). Responses are estimated from CAM6 simulations with interactive atmospheric chemistry coupled to a slab ocean model over the last 150 years of the simulation (years 50–199).Full size imageReduced dust burden under tree restoration is consistent with reduced near-surface wind speeds (due to enhanced surface roughness), as discussed in ref. 24 (e.g., see Supplementary Fig. 12 from that paper). For example, near-surface wind speeds over land decrease by \(-0.11\pm 0.01\) m s−1 under both \({{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{2{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}}\) and \({{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{1{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}}.\) The weaker surface winds, in turn, favor less dust emissions, with similar decreases under both \({{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{2{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}}\) and \({{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{1{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}}\), i.e., dust emissions nonsignificantly decrease by \(-44.1\pm 85.4\) Tg year−1 under \({{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{2{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}}-{{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{1{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}}\).Consistent with the standard approach in most current climate models, our simulations do not include interactive fire emissions (see the “Methods” section) of PM2.5 and its precursors. They are instead read in from a time-varying emissions file (here fixed in the base year of 2000). As discussed below, fire carbon emissions do change in response to our tree restoration perturbation, including significant global increases under \({{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{2{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}}-{{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{1{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}}\), largely in the NH (Supplementary Table 5). This implies the above-quoted PM2.5 increases under \({{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{2{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}}-{{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{1{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}}\) are likely an underestimate, at least in the areas downwind of where there are increases in fire activity.Supplementary Figure 4 shows changes in near-surface ozone (O3), another commonly used quantity to diagnose air quality. Over land in the NH, O3 increases under both \({{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{2{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}}\) (\(0.90\pm 0.07\) ppb) and \({{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{1{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}}\) (\(0.78\pm 0.07\) ppb), with net increases under \({{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{2{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}}-{{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{1{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}}\) (\(0.12\pm 0.10\) ppb). Some regions (e.g., central US) experience relatively large increases under both \({{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{2{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}}\) and \({{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{1{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}}\) (>5 ppb or a 20–25% increase relative to the control), which is consistent with relatively high levels on NOx (based on the year 2000 baseline) and BVOCs, leading to enhanced O3. In the SH, the opposite occurs with decreases under both \({{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{2{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}}\) (\(-0.86\pm 0.04\) ppb) and \({{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{1{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}}\) (\(-0.14\pm 0.04\) ppb), with net decreases under \({{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{2{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}}-{{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{1{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}}\) (\(-0.71\pm 0.05\) ppb). The SH features smaller levels of NOx, and here the enhanced BVOC oxidation of O3 dominates, with the larger increase in BVOCs (e.g., Fig. 3a, b) under \({{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{2{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}}\) yielding a larger decrease in O3. We also note that these O3 changes are also consistent with changes in ozone deposition velocity (estimated as monthly ozone dry deposition flux divided by monthly near-surface ozone concentration; Supplementary Fig. 5). For example, over NH land (where O3 increases) ozone deposition velocity strongly decreases by \(-0.091\pm 0.004\) mm s−1 under \({{TREE}}_{2{xCo}2}\) and by \(-0.087\pm 0.003\) mm s−1 under \({{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{1{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}}\) (Supplementary Table 3). NH decreases in ozone deposition velocity with tree restoration may occur following decreases in transpiration that follow the displacement of highly productive crops and grasses as well as decreased near-surface wind speed that follows increases in roughness and leads to less efficient vertical transport of ozone (see supplement of ref. 24). In the SH, ozone deposition velocity weakly increases by \(0.0033\pm 0.0031\) mm s−1 under \({{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{2{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}}\) (where O3 decreases), with decreases of \(-0.025\pm 0.002\) mm s−1 under \({{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{1{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}}\) (where O3 increases). The corresponding \({{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{2{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}}\) spatial correlations for the NH and SH land are \(-0.81\) and \(-0.22\), respectively (\(-0.66\) for global land). For \({{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{1{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}}\), the NH and SH land correlations are \(-0.88\) and \(-0.46\), respectively (\(-0.80\) for global land). \({{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{2{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}}-{{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{1{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}}\) effects on ozone deposition velocity are mostly at higher mid-latitudes, and they are decreases. These decreases occur despite strong increases in LAI under \({{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{2{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}}-{{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{1{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}}\), which may be due to compensatory changes in individual depositional processes55,56. Enhanced ozone deposition velocity under \({{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{2{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}}-{{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{1{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}}\) in the SH largely follows enhanced LAI there. This is likely due to enhanced cuticular uptake, as stomatal uptake largely decreases. Cuticular uptake is independent of stomatal uptake and occurs when ozone reacts with compounds adhered to or a part of leaf cuticles.Overall, \({{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{2{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}}-{{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{1{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}}\) yields degraded air quality in the NH for both O3 and PM2.5. In the SH, \({{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{2{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}}-{{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{1{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}}\) yields improved air quality in terms of O3, but degraded air quality in terms of PM2.5. These statements are more pronounced over regions with large tree restoration (e.g., Brazil).Fire and land carbon responsesFigure 5 shows the fire carbon emissions response to tree restoration. \({{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{1{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}}\) yields overall (global) decreases in fire carbon emissions at \(-195.8\pm 30.7\) TgC year−1 (\(-10.9\)%), with significant decreases in the tropics (30S-30N) of \(-307.7\pm 27.5\) TgC year−1 (\(-22.1\)%) outweighing significant increases in the NH extratropics (NHE; 30–60 N) and SH extratropics (SHE; 30–60S) at \(96.1\pm 10.8\) TgC year−1 (\(34.2\)%) and \(16.2\pm 6.2\) TgC year−1 (\(13.4\)%), respectively (Supplementary Table 5). Similar conclusions apply under \({{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{2{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}}\), but with muted global decreases (\(-46.9\pm 39.8\) TgC year−1), i.e., \({{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{2{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}}-{{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{1{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}}\) yields a net increase of \(148.9\pm 47.9\) TgC year−1. This is mostly related to larger increases under \({{{\rm{TREE}}}}_{2{x{{{\rm{Co}}}}}_{2}}\) in the NHE (\(162.1\pm 18.4\) TgC year−1) and weaker decreases in the tropics (\(-218.5\pm 36.0\) TgC year−1) i.e., \({{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{2{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}}-{{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{1{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}}\) yields net increases in the NHE and tropics of \(65.9\pm 21.3\) and \(89.2\pm 42.1\) TgC year−1, respectively. These signals are partially offset by weaker increases in the SHE (\(9.3\pm 4.0\) TgC year−1) under \({{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{2{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}}\) (i.e., \({{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{2{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}}-{{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{1{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}}\) yields nonsignificant net decreases of \(-6.9\pm 7.4\) TgC year−1). Thus, \({{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{2{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}}-{{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{1{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}}\) exacerbates fire carbon emissions (and fire burned area), largely in the NHE and tropics.Fig. 5: Fire responses to global tree restoration.a–e Fire carbon emissions [kgC km−2 day−1] responses based on simulations with interactive chemistry under a \({{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{2{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}}\) and b \({{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{1{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}}\) and c \({{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{2{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}}-{{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{1{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}}\). Error bars in d and e show the 90% confidence interval.Full size imageReasons for this do not appear to be related to the climate response to tree restoration (e.g., in CLM5 fuel combustibility depends on soil moisture and relative humidity and fire spread depends on wind speed; see the “Methods” section). For example, the NHE features significant net cooling as well as net moistening based on both relative humidity at 2 m (RH2M) and soil water in the top 10 cm (SW10CM) under \({{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{2{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}}-{{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{1{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}}\) (Supplementary Table 5). Near-surface wind speeds do feature significant net increases in the NHE, but this is a smaller decrease under \({{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{2{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}}\). We suspect the increase in fire carbon emissions under \({{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{2{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}}\) in the NHE and the weaker decrease in the tropics is related to the warmer and drier background climate. Comparing the \({{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{2{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}}\) baseline climate versus the \({{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{1{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}}\) baseline climate shows very large NHE increases in fire carbon emissions of 167%, as well as strong NHE drying based on RH2M (\(-2.0 \%\)) and, in particular, based on SW10CM \((-9.7 \% )\)). Similar but weaker drying occur in the tropics. Interestingly, the opposite changes occur in the SHE, where fire carbon emissions nonsignificantly decrease by \(-3.3 \%\), RH2M significantly increases by \(1.9 \%\), and SW10CM weakly decreases by \(-0.6 \%\). Thus, the larger NHE increase (and smaller tropical decrease) in fire carbon emissions under \({{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{2{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}}\) appears to be related to the warmer and drier background climate. This argument also helps to explain the weaker SHE increase in fire carbon emissions under \({{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{2{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}}\), where drying is muted (e.g., RH2M increases).Land carbon (the sum of vegetation, litter, and soil organic matter carbon) increases under both \({TREE}_{2xCo2}\) and \({{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{1{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}}\) (Fig. 6a–c), with larger increases under \({{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{2{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}}\). Similar statements apply to vegetation carbon (Fig. 6d–f), litter carbon (Fig. 6g–i) and soil organic matter carbon (Fig. 6j–l), with vegetation carbon dominating the increase. By the last decade of the simulation (years 190–199), global land carbon (Fig. 6c) increases by \(306.1\pm 1.9\) PgC under \({{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{2{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}}\) versus \(210.3\pm 0.7\) PgC under \({{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{1{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}}\) (Supplementary Table 6). \({{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{2{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}}-{{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{1{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}}\) therefore yields enhanced land carbon storage of \(95.8\pm 1.0\) PgC, which represents a 46% increase relative to \({{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{1{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}}\). Similarly, the global increase in net primary productivity (NPP; Supplementary Table 5) is larger under \({{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{2{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}}\) at \(2257.5\pm 280.6\) TgC year−1 as compared to \({{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{1{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}}\) at \(700.3\pm 193.4\) TgC year−1. This enhanced NPP and land carbon storage response under \({{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{2{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}}\) is consistent with the carbon fertilization effect57,58,59,60.Fig. 6: Land carbon time series.Global annual mean a–c vegetation + litter + soil organic matter carbon; d–f vegetation carbon; g–i litter carbon; and j–l soil organic matter carbon responses for the a, d, g, j Northern Hemisphere; b, e, h, k Southern Hemisphere; and c, f, I, l globe. Units are PgC.Full size imageThe transient climate response to cumulative CO2 emissions (TCRE) represents a near-linear relationship between cumulative anthropogenic CO2 emissions and global warming since the preindustrial, and provides an approximation of the near-surface air temperature response to land carbon changes32,33,34,35. We note that there is uncertainty in using this approach to quantify the biogeochemical cooling effects associated with tree restoration. Ideally, emissions-driven simulations would be employed, which directly simulate the carbon cycle and allow a direct estimate of the biogeochemical effects associated with tree restoration. This includes compensation by the marine carbon sink as atmospheric CO2 decreases in response to an increase in terrestrial carbon storage61,62,63.Using the CESM2 TCRE value34 of 2.13 K per 1000 PgC and the increase in global land carbon storage (years 190–199) yields an estimate of the associated biogeochemical cooling of \(-0.65\) K under \({{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{2{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}}\) versus \(-0.45\) K under \({{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{1{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}}\), i.e., \({{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{2{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}}-{{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{1{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}}\) yields enhanced biogeochemical cooling of \(-0.20\) K. We note that the CESM2 TCRE is on the high end64, as the best estimate is 1.65 K per 1000 PgC, with a likely range from 1.0 to 2.3 K per 1000 PgC.ERF and radiative kernel decompositionFigure 7 shows the instantaneous radiative forcing (IRF), total adjustment (Totaladj) and effective radiative forcing (ERF, which is the sum of IRF and Totaladj; see the “Methods” section) from analogous tree restoration simulations with climatologically fixed SSTs and sea-ice distributions (FSST; see the “Methods” section). IRF is estimated as the sum of the surface albedo radiative kernel (IRFalbedo) and the ADRE (IRFADRE; calculated online from double radiation calls). Although most ERFs are not significant, they qualitatively support the temperature responses from the corresponding SOM simulations. For example, NH ERF decreases from \(0.18\pm 0.10\) W m−2 under \({{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{1{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}}\) to \(0.01\pm 0.16\) W m−2 under \({{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{2{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}}\), consistent with muted NH warming under \({{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{2{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}}\) (Fig. 1). \({{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{2{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}}-{{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{1{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}}\) therefore yields a negative (but not significant) NH ERF of \(-0.17\pm 0.19\) W m−2, also consistent with NH net surface cooling under \({{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{2{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}}-{{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{1{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}}\) in SOM simulations. Similar results exist for the land surface corrected ERF (ERFts). Most of the negative ERF under \({{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{2{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}}-{{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{1{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}}\) is due to a less positive IRF under \({{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{2{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}}\) as compared to \({{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{1{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}}\) (i.e., the IRF under \({{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{2{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}}-{{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{1{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}}\) is \(-0.13\pm 0.06\) W m−2). This is associated with a less positive IRFalbedo (less surface darkening) and a more negative IRFADRE (consistent with more SOA) under \({{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{2{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}}\). The corresponding \({{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{2{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}}-{{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{1{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}}\) effects are \(-0.05\pm 0.03\) W m−2 for IRFalbedo and \(-0.08\pm 0.05\) W m−2 for IRFADRE. In addition to IRF, adjustments also impact ERF. Here, the cloud adjustment is less negative under \({{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{2{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}}\), i.e., there is a (nonsignificant) positive cloud adjustment under \({{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{2{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}}-{{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{1{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}}\) of \(0.06\pm 0.09\) W m−2 based on the kernel difference method (\(0.03\) W m−2 based on ISCCP Cloudadj). This positive cloud adjustment acts to mute some of the negative IRF under \({{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{2{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}}-{{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{1{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}}\). Note, however, that non-cloud adjustments (largely the tropospheric temperature adjustment) dominate and contribute to the decreased ERF (i.e., the Totaladj is negative but with large uncertainty at \(-0.04\pm 0.16\) W m−2). Thus, these FSST simulations support the above SOM analyses—most of the NH surface cooling under \({{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{2{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}}-{{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{1{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}}\) is consistent with less surface darkening and enhanced aerosol scattering (IRFalbedo and IRFADRE, respectively), which is partially weakened by clouds (23% for ISCCP Cloudadj and 46% for Cloudadj).Fig. 7: ERF and radiative kernel decomposition from fixed SST simulations.Annual mean TOA effective radiative forcing (ERF; black), land surface corrected ERF (ERFts; red), instantaneous radiative forcing (IRF; light green) which is decomposed into contributions from albedo (IRFalbedo; dark green) and aerosol direct radiative effects (IRFADRE; medium green), the cloud adjustment from the kernel difference method (Cloudadj; light pink) and from the ISCCP simulator combined with the ISCCP radiative kernel (ISCCP Cloudadj; dark pink) and the total adjustment (Totaladj; blue) for the a Northern Hemisphere and b Southern Hemisphere.
